title: Toys, Secrets, and Cycles: Lessons from the 2000s
body:
I started my internet career in the early 2000s during the dot-com bust. It's hard to picture this now, but the internet was a thing that people used only intermittently, to check email or plan travel or do some research. The average internet user spent about 30 minutes a day online, compared to about 7 hours today. To use the internet, you had to sit down in front of a desktop PC and "log on" (most people still had dial-up), nothing like the always-on, high-speed mobile internet we use today. In 2001, Amazon's stock price hit an [all-time](https://companiesmarketcap.com/amazon/marketcap/) [low](https://www.zdnet.com/article/amazon-cash-to-run-dry-by-2001/), with a market cap of $2.2B, about 1/500th of what it is today. A prominent research firm [published](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2003/05/18/broadband-adoption-at-home/) a study asking Americans if they'd adopt broadband and the majority said no. Email was the most popular internet use case and they didn’t see the need to make it faster. The National Academy of Sciences [ranked](http://www.greatachievements.org/) the internet 13th in its list of great inventions over the last 100 years, beneath radio and telephones. The mainstream consensus was that the internet was a cool invention, but had limited use cases, and probably wasn't a good place to build a business.

At the same time, there was a small but growing movement of developers and founders who were excited about the idea that the internet could be more than a read-only medium – that it could allow anyone to create and publish, to not only read but also write, as we said back then. This movement became known as web 2. The runner up name was read-write web. (These are not after-the-fact terms: there were [prominent](https://www.oreilly.com/pub/a/web2/archive/what-is-web-20.html) publications and conferences that used them.)

The key web 2 concepts were: letting users publish whatever they want (“user generated content” was a buzzword), social graphs, APIs and [mashups](https://avc.com/2006/08/business_develo/) (what we'd call [composability](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1451703067213066244?s=20&t=OMwnAHagQ1wsTRv-Bre-wA) today), defaulting profiles and photos to public vs private, and tagging over hierarchical navigation, among other things. There were also technical innovations. A seemingly simple but important one was web pages that updated dynamically without reloading the page, what was usually called [Ajax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming)) and is now just the way people expect web apps to work. There were mobile devices that could access the open web but they were extremely niche (I was an avid [Sidekick](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMNDqO2HjEU) user).

One striking thing about that period was the contrast between what smart founders and engineers talked about at dinner and on weekends and what the mainstream tech world took seriously during work days. For example, one popular mainstream trend was enterprise security appliances, which were basically servers preloaded with security software. Many of the very same people would go to work and talk about the “serious” products, and then go to dinner, or hang out on the weekends, and talk about consumer internet products and web 2. It was the most interesting thing happening in tech. But generally, the view was, web 2 products were toys that couldn't be real businesses. They were hobbies, and not something you would take seriously during the workday.

One lesson for me, which took me some time to learn, and that eventually led to some blog posts I wrote, including “[The next thing big thing will start out looking like a toy](https://cdixon.org/2010/01/03/the-next-big-thing-will-start-out-looking-like-a-toy)” and “[What the smartest people do on the weekend is what everyone else will do during the week in ten years](https://cdixon.org/2013/03/02/what-the-smartest-people-do-on-the-weekend-is-what-everyone-else-will-do-during-the-week-in-ten-years),” is that there's a strong correlation between rich product design spaces and what smart people find interesting. Web 2 was captivating, and led to so many dinner and weekend conversations, because there were so many novel product design possibilities. What if you took this feature and that feature and combined them? What if you applied this design pattern to a different context? What original product concepts would be invented next? This is what got people so excited. In contrast, the “serious stuff,” security appliances and such, seemed much more limited in their possibilities. 

Another striking thing about that period was how small and passionate the web 2 community was. I remember in 2004 going to what I think might have been the first New York Tech meetup. The whole group fit in a small room in Meetup’s headquarters. People demoed software they had created and talked late into the evening. I still have friends from that period. Sometimes I get asked how I first met old friends like Fred Wilson and Alex Ohanian. The simple answer is there just weren't that many people, especially on the east coast, who were interested in these topics. We all knew each other. It was a real community. I have one old friend Alex Rampell (who now works with me at a16z) who I met in 2003 because a friend of mine was at a dinner party and afterwards said “Hey, I met someone else who's interested in consumer internet.” It was that rare. But people were very focused and excited. The feeling was that a revolution was brewing. We knew a secret and the rest of the world hadn't figured it out yet.

As for me, I was working on my own web 2 startup called SiteAdvisor. Around 2003, when my co-founders and I started developing the concept, web security threats were spiraling out of control. Most people used PCs with Internet Explorer, and problems like phishing and spyware were widespread. The idea for SiteAdvisor was that we’d start off with a tool that would warn users about security threats like phishing and spyware, and then, over time, applying web 2 concepts like user-generated reviews, layer on more subjective judgements (similar to what [TrustPilot](https://www.trustpilot.com/) seems to do today). This staged approach was common at the time, a strategy I later characterized as “[Come for the tool, stay for the network](https://cdixon.org/2015/01/31/come-for-the-tool-stay-for-the-network).” We built APIs and encouraged mashups and did most of our marketing through SEO.  

2005 was a big year for web 2 because of two acquisitions, Flickr and Delicious, both by Yahoo. The dollar values were small by today’s standards, something like $30M each, but it was an important signal. The assumption up until then was that web 2 was a fun hobby, a way to build cool stuff, but not something that would produce real businesses. Yahoo was considered a savvy company, and said they were making web 2 a core part of their strategy. 

As I recall, that was the point when web 2 started transitioning from a niche cult movement into mainstream tech. Some of the early web 2 founders successfully made the transition. In other cases new entrepreneurs came along who built on the work of the early enthusiasts. The basis of competition switched from creative idea generation to disciplined execution. You had to decide whether you wanted to be the idealistic band at the indy bar or be pragmatic — potentially making compromises — and play in stadiums. 

By 2007, things were looking up for web 2. Among other things, Facebook passed 10M users, Twitter was growing and had just gotten VC funded, and Google acquired YouTube. Then the 2008 financial crisis hit, which was a gut check for entrepreneurs. Tech funding dried up, and a lot of smart people said we were on the [verge](https://articles.sequoiacap.com/rip-good-times) of another great depression.

The financial downturn was a difficult time for many people. But from a startup perspective, the 2008-11 era turned out to be a golden age. Apple released the iPhone app store in 2008 and by 2009 talented founders were pouring in. The mobile app revolution was in full swing. Almost all of today’s top mobile apps were created by companies founded between 2009 and 2011, including Uber, Venmo, Snap, and Instagram. In retrospect, there was a convergence of three powerful trends: social media (by then that word was replacing web 2), cloud computing (which would enable the apps to scale server side), and the rise of smartphones. Independent product design spaces are multiplicative: even if social, cloud, and mobile each improved linearly, the combination could improve exponentially.

I made the chart below to summarize how I've come to think about product and financial cycles. The key idea is that product and financial cycles evolve mostly independently. The top of the chart shows the Nasdaq index as a rough proxy for financial sentiment. Financial sentiment fluctuates unpredictably and sometimes wildly. 

The next row shows the years that iconic startups or products were created. The timing is mostly dictated by product cycles, which are shown in the bottom row. Product cycles follow their own internal logic and tend to be more predictable than financial cycles. They begin with the incubation phase when enthusiasts explore ideas on nights and weekends and build products that are mostly used by other enthusiasts. The growth phase arrives when the right mix of technology, talent, and community knowledge comes together to enable the products to go mainstream. (I show the biggest tech cycles in the chart, but smaller, offshoot tech cycles happen as well, including web 2 in the 2000s, and things like fintech and SaaS in the 2010s.)

![Financial cycles and product cycles](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Ps4OuwnY01u396r29UKzn.png?height=1174&width=1554)

Tech is very different today than in the 2000s. A handful of tech incumbents dominate the internet, exerting vast economic and cultural influence. In the 2000s, web 2 was mostly ignored or dismissed as techies talking about trivialities. Today, entrenched interests aggressively respond to new movements that might someday threaten them. But the same creative patterns that happened in the 2000s live on today, driven by enthusiasts who see possibilities where others don’t. You just need to know where to look. My belief is that the best place to look is crypto and web 3.

From my vantage point, today’s negative financial sentiment most closely resembles 2008. If we are headed for a prolonged downturn, there are some tactical lessons from the 2008 era, namely preserving capital and staying focused on your long-term vision. The strategic lesson is to keep your eyes squarely focused on the product cycle. Things that look interesting to smart people usually do so because they are rich with product possibilities. These possibilities eventually become reality. Toys become must-have tools. Weekend hobbies become mainstream activities. Cynics sound smart but optimists build the future.

title: Trophic Syntheos
body:
Trophic Syntheos is intended to prompt systems design dialogue.

“…the most obvious important realities are often the ones that are hardest to see and talk about.” - David Foster Wallace

![Trophic Syntheos](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jhBOSIcjqSBtxzKih6Jk4.jpg?height=4192&width=4704&size=large)

**Trophic Syntheos is a meandering thought of systems wholeness, intergrations and expansions.** 

*[Trophic](https://www.wordnik.com/words/trophic)* is derived from Ancient Greek *trophikos*, "pertaining to food or nourishment. *Syntheos* is also from the Greeks: *syn*- for ***with*** or ***creating with***; *theos* referring to ***god***. [Syntheism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntheism) is a kind of religion just as Buddhism is a kind of religion. Kind of, but not at all. These are traditions of practice, experience and inquiry into the felt moment. [Spiritual naturalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiritual_naturalism) is said to be America’s version of Syntheism, however the whole movement is somewhat small. 

*Trophic syntheos* to me evokes a deep connecting with, within and as the living mystery surrounding us. A connecting; an intuition; a resonance. Would you say that trophic syntheos must be something we must trust as being true. It’s far too grand to hold and hug. It’s a [hyperobject](https://books.google.com.au/books?hl=en&lr=&id=qu5zDwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PT9&ots=mb9dzyCRfW&sig=43u98RlwxrZETvmCKacwd7jX-Tg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false), just like polystyrene or anthropocentric climate heating. Trophic syntheos is an ambition, a dream and a possibility of practice. Trophic syntheos is an idea hiding in liminal corners of our collective psyche. The overwhelmingly massive hyperobjects are distributed across time and space so our collective intelligence and wisdom should be too. It is never too late to fall in love with the living world and fight in its name despite the enormity of our collective damage. 

![Logo used by The Syntheist Movement](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Rs3ThgHeoHa5YsjBUjQFJ.png?height=1920&width=1920)

I love this quote and I think it’s why I felt inspired to think of this graphic, french philosopher Quentin Meillassoux [writes](https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/after-finitude-9781441173836/) "God is a concept far too important to leave to the religious." And isn’t that right…? 

I’d be really interested to hear your reflections on this. In my life, I feel a spiritual connection with the world around me, especially on bushwalks and camping trips, and especially during and as a result of psychedelic experiences. This is an everyday wonder and gratitude for being here. The amazement that everything else is here too never ceases to impact me. And that we are here together is unreal. 

But our experiences have no container to hold the broader and broadest communities together. It feels so disparate: unequal; dissimilar; separate. And my hunch is that that’s just part of the neo-liberal hellscape that has emerged over the last century (or maybe five, or maybe 100?). We are so siloed and in opposition. 

I love spending time in nature. I feel grateful to live in a place where it is everywhere. 

I hate seeing nature in decline. I feel, as you likely do if you’re bothering to read this, that it is everywhere. I know it to be the case, I consume news, and I’ve travelled enough. Nature is being destroyed in every pocket of this glorious place. 

Nature is our god. That is just an obvious truth. Life and nutrition hold the keys to possibilities, without one or the other there is either unknown stuff, or there is nothing. Life depends on - and is - nutrition. Nutrition is just unknown stuff if there is no life to consume and become it, so I guess it is as good as nothing too.

![Amphorae vessels](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/DhUChGE1GXi3xGknE4soz.jpeg?height=1680&width=1662)

**Vessels    |**    We need vessels to contain all this life and nutrition for this is everything we are made of. And then we need larger vessels, that can hold those first vessels, to hold all that we become together. And so on. 

Isn’t it striking to consider the ocean, the ship, the [vase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphora#Etymology), the human body and the human mind all as vessels with varying dimensions of containment? 

The ocean somehow contains the liquid vastness the ship sails across. The vase contains the wine that is stored below deck. Our bodies drink the wine, it stirs a mind into fervor. 

There is activity and containment everywhere. At each membrane, vessels press into one another with interest. The ocean is faithfully thirsty to swallow the sailors, their vessels, bodies and minds into its depths until they gather at the nexal point and are subject to annealing. Boarders, barriers, seals and edges become nothing more than fish food and parts of bodies. What once was held in containment is annexed into some greater arrangement.

Apparently, the association between hollow utensils and boats appears in all languages. Surely that points to a universal knowing. We are alive in the same nested realities as our neighbours. Yet somehow we have constructed a worldview of difference and indifference. 

It seems absurd the degree with which those with some much nutrition - so much stuff - want to continue accumulating to the point where life is extinguished. It really really is like [Mr Creosote](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxRnenQYG7I). There are so many lifeless minds addicted to consumption. 

[Consumerism is an evil ideology](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gK9L0N9tf1U&t=46s). And just like neoliberalism, and just like the ocean consumerism is a very broad vessel. It’s difficult to see land but it is getting clearer and closer with each day. A few decades ago we were stuck in the middle of the widest part - between shorelines of sacred knowing; of trophic syntheos I guess.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/BOSKzzAG_hrjoA60_toPP.png?height=688&width=1608)

The visibility of home is increasing along with the turbulence of the churning sides of wherever we are, or whatever we are in. 

We really can do without the opposing worldviews that are incongruent with trophic syntheos.

I guess ***trophic syntheos*** must refer to the “god” in all that can be food, or all that is life.

title: YuHwa's Diary #1 - June 27th 2022

title: advancement
body:
The advancement of modern technology is making peoples life more comfortable and at the same time less human. To those who enjoy the benefits of technology, there is no better time to be alive than now, but to others life has been increasingly complex and stressful. The issue is whether such new technological machines as computers and the Internet would be our servants forever or eventually could become our masters.

　　All kinds of inventions made possible by technology are designed to be the slaves of human beings, if human beings are not to be slaved by machines. Once upon a time, we were plain people, but that was before we began having relationships with technological systems. By getting involved with computerized machines, we could not help changing the way we live and the way we work, for better or for worse It can be realized that life is more complex because much of modern technology is not born to meet primary human needs, and many unnecessary inventions are producing negative effects on a living style that used to be relatively simple. Thus, there is an overwhelming feeling of complexity in the sense that machines act like humans and humans act like machines. Now that intelligent machines such as robots are widely applied to take the place of human beings because they are capable of doing many useful jobs, although making many people joblesss. Those who cannot work with computers are disadvantaged and therefore helpless while the traditional skills and simple ways of life are fading away, never to return again.

title: Avalanche - 對戰鏈遊 Crabada 入門指南
body:
### 前言：

Crabada 是一款玩家通過養成寄居蟹戰士來闖關及互相對戰，已獲得經驗值與收益的 Play to earn 鏈遊。現階段收益主要來自於我們在遊戲中賺取到的代幣 TUS，TUS 除了是遊戲中的貨幣也是 Crabada 在 Avalanche 的 Subnet “Swimmer Network”  中的 Gas token，在價值捕獲上有不錯的規劃，若日後有越來越多的遊戲加入 Swimmer Network 活絡生態的話，或許 TUS 價值會有相應的增長可能性（官方DC有透露目前已在接洽幾款鏈遊，確切內容還是以官方公告為主～）。

此次我們介紹的重點為如何入門 Crabada 在 2022 年 Q1 最新上線的 Battle Game。除了原先的放置玩法，此次更新還新增了遊戲闖關模式及玩家 PvP 模式，大大提升了遊戲的樂趣及玩家間的互動性。就讓我們來看看如何加入 Crabada 的世界吧！


---

### 遊戲前的準備：

在開始遊戲前我們有以下幾件事需要做：
（雖然步驟稍多，但相信學會後你日後在雪崩子網玩耍的日子會更加的得心應手！）

1. 轉一些 Avax 作為瓦斯費到 Avalanche C-Chain。
2. 在 Metamask 新增 Swimmer Network 網路。
3. 創建 Crabada 帳號。
4. 去 Trader Joe 換一些 TUS 作為 Swimmer Network 的 Gas 及等一下買寄居蟹戰士NFT 的錢。
5. 把 TUS bridge 到 Swimmer Network。
6. 購買寄居蟹戰士NFT。
7. 將寄居蟹戰士NFT轉移到 Game account 中。
8. 下載 APP 開始遊戲。

> **第一步｜轉 Avax 到 Avalanche C-Chain**

若你的 Metamask 沒有 Avalanche C-Chain，可以直接去 [Chainlist](https://chainlist.org/zh) 網站新增。

Avax 建議透過中心化交易所提幣到 C-Chain 上最簡單安全，若您在其他鏈上有資產也可選擇使用 [Bungee](https://www.bungee.exchange/refuel) 之類的去中心化跨鏈橋跨到雪崩上，建議跨約40u等值左右的資產過來（必須有一些 Avax 當 Gas 剩下的可以是 usdc 之類的）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/SY_oaQL7CdssbjAF_ZIDb.png?height=637&width=1331)

> **第二步｜新增 Swimmer Network 網路**

直接進入 [Carbada 的 Market](https://market.crabada.com/) 連上錢包後，若無 Swimmer Network 網路它會直接幫你加入並讓你切換過去。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RVPOYbX9QFQLKPUumJWwB.png?height=668&width=1160)

> **第三步｜創建 Crabada 帳號**

點擊 Login 簽署過後，去到 Account 頁面點 Register now 把 Email 設定好，我們在登入遊戲 APP 時會需要 Email 收登入用的 OTP 碼。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ZV7Ql7-46tAtST7htO-N2.png?height=700&width=1171)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_f7Nvw2HfXoGQ5qct-oQg.png?height=600&width=1195)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/CgDlChk3xDvDKGXBPt4eK.png?height=688&width=1194)

> **第四步｜兌換 TUS**

點擊 Buy tokens 選 TUS，會自動開啟 Trader Joe 幫你跳回 C-Chain 並 import TUS 代幣進Swap，你只要兌換你需要的數量即可（可以先看看市場3隻地板價寄居蟹大概要多少 TUS）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HHx0nKuMoiWKpuv4gu3np.png?height=261&width=1144)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/h_aX-X96E9K4slW6t0-Z7.png?height=650&width=1154)

> **第五步｜把 TUS bridge 到 Swimmer Network**

我們買到的 TUS 是在 C-Chain 上，我們需要把它橋到 Swimmer Network 上，很簡單我們回到 Carbada 的Account 頁面，點擊 Bridge 會新開一個 Swimmer Network 各種橋的頁面，選擇 Layer Zero Bridge（From: Avalanche ; To: Swimmer Network ; Token: TUS），確定好數量按 Bridge。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/EPHQEZEVqOOautfh3MlO6.png?height=397&width=1200)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Y-rkNVBDNmtN8TYy2SOil.png?height=738&width=1131)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/pRkZKN_1R1xtJ9P5x-Fwm.png?height=661&width=1200)

> **第六步｜購買寄居蟹戰士NFT**

現在我們 Swimmer Network 上有 TUS 了，終於可以去 Marketplace 買自己喜歡的寄居蟹戰士了，大家一開始先從地板價挑 3 隻買就可以了，建議至少買一隻坦克類型的（Fraction:ORE，下圖這四隻就是坦克屬性）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/W7yu6IZyLU2oLuWOplikv.png?height=668&width=1369)

> **第七步｜將寄居蟹戰士NFT轉移到 Game account 中**

到 Account 頁面點擊 Transfer Crabada 勾選剛剛買的 Crabada 轉移到 Game account！

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/MpGZ0FTDaqbbEu_y9SMXB.png?height=399&width=1197)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/uoJVVMnF8cy0zN3vA3Zdi.png?height=781&width=1197)

到[官方網站](https://www.crabada.com/#battle)下載自己裝置版本的遊戲 App ，下載完後進入 App 選擇 Login 填入 Email 點 Send code，信箱會收到 OTP 使用其密碼進入遊戲。恭喜你成功開始 Crabada 的旅程了！

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/d1iBooPncHCBNGPJnBzxj.png?height=490&width=1329)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KV4fTYYV9ksM-lvfjIW8J.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/AOL449gQiu50IuAA0JZUq.png?height=1080&width=2340)


---

### 遊戲模式介紹

OK！ 現在我們完成了所有準備步驟，終於可以開始玩遊戲了！目前遊戲內容大致分為以下幾種模式，我會一一進行簡單的介紹！

1. 冒險模式
2. 挖寶模式
3. 搶劫模式
4. 角色升等
5. 戰利品兌換
6. PvP模式

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KNfpWkmZCWvLGk0LDKZQW.png?height=475&width=1033)

> **1 - 冒險模式**

使用你的 Crabada 3隻一組組成隊伍闖關，可以無限次嘗試可過關的擺陣方式與組合～（放前排的角色會優先被攻擊，如果同一排沒有攻擊目標會優先轉而攻擊上面一排的角色）

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vfxmradxsqi7ByxMEYA6t.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/N4dHRFMIVAybvIevsMi3H.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/VwLY1ri8AHsfj0zEy-Fty.png?height=1080&width=2340)

> **2 - 挖寶模式**

送你的 Crabada 出去挖礦，是我們主要的獲利方式。一次 1 小時，花費 4 點閃電點數（用完了每天會回滿）。挖礦時會有人來搶劫你，會自動發生戰鬥，贏或輸會影響獎勵（下圖可以看到角色屬性克制圖），時間到了再回來 Claim 獎勵即可，挖礦期間還是可以繼續玩闖關模式沒問題的！

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/tpAPxy4VqdIRNB09CE8A4.png?height=565&width=1227)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/VCgjT2gWVTURWJv2DbC4t.png?height=559&width=1224)

> **3 - 搶劫模式**

除了挖礦，我們也可以選擇去搶劫別人（也是會發生戰鬥），每次 30 分鐘，花費 1 點閃電。輸贏影響獎勵，時間到了可去 Claim。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0L2od2gmGU2-aIvlOdaBr.png?height=563&width=1225)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/I53ISJC8ExAjWGZ5f9Dk3.png?height=562&width=1224)

> **4 - 角色升等**

為了在每次戰鬥無往不利，我們的角色需要升等，也需要餵飽。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-UToWDYXjGfQ2ZaaS7ZtR.png?height=495&width=1073)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1ZtEdGgbqRgI98Jrw5DyU.png?height=591&width=1243)

> **5 - 戰利品兌換**

透過挖礦與搶劫獲得的戰利品，可以在此換成 TUS 或是食物。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vWid8z1-v23t9MZM2IawZ.png?height=1080&width=2340)

> **6 - PvP 模式**

最新的模式，官方即將開放新的錦標賽功能。目前我們可以透過 Host 創建挑戰，或是通過 Scan 加入別人的挑戰，來跟其他玩家的隊伍進行PK。贏家可以拿回 Duel Cost，輸家的 Duel Cost 則會被燒掉（而不是被贏家獲得）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/MkKdXvWPFk-FMtVM_3_H7.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/I5z5kQPYd800Nwzedmvpc.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/GZqsZiJdZ9ff4vmzG2vmw.png?height=1080&width=2340)


---

### 結尾

至此已經將整個入門 Crabada 的流程完整的順過一遍了。祝大家可以愉快的遊戲，獲得不錯的收益與遊戲體驗囉～ Peace Out！

2. 在 Metamask 新增 Swimmer Network 網路。
3. 創建 Crabada 帳號。
4. 去 Trader Joe 換一些 TUS 作為 Swimmer Network 的 Gas 及等一下買寄居蟹戰士NFT 的錢。
5. 把 TUS bridge 到 Swimmer Network。
6. 購買寄居蟹戰士NFT。
7. 將寄居蟹戰士NFT轉移到 Game account 中。
8. 下載 APP 開始遊戲。

> **第一步｜轉 Avax 到 Avalanche C-Chain**

若你的 Metamask 沒有 Avalanche C-Chain，可以直接去 [Chainlist](https://chainlist.org/zh) 網站新增。

Avax 建議透過中心化交易所提幣到 C-Chain 上最簡單安全，若您在其他鏈上有資產也可選擇使用 [Bungee](https://www.bungee.exchange/refuel) 之類的去中心化跨鏈橋跨到雪崩上，建議跨約40u等值左右的資產過來（必須有一些 Avax 當 Gas 剩下的可以是 usdc 之類的）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/SY_oaQL7CdssbjAF_ZIDb.png?height=637&width=1331)

> **第二步｜新增 Swimmer Network 網路**

直接進入 [Carbada 的 Market](https://market.crabada.com/) 連上錢包後，若無 Swimmer Network 網路它會直接幫你加入並讓你切換過去。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RVPOYbX9QFQLKPUumJWwB.png?height=668&width=1160)

> **第三步｜創建 Crabada 帳號**

點擊 Login 簽署過後，去到 Account 頁面點 Register now 把 Email 設定好，我們在登入遊戲 APP 時會需要 Email 收登入用的 OTP 碼。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ZV7Ql7-46tAtST7htO-N2.png?height=700&width=1171)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_f7Nvw2HfXoGQ5qct-oQg.png?height=600&width=1195)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/CgDlChk3xDvDKGXBPt4eK.png?height=688&width=1194)

> **第四步｜兌換 TUS**

點擊 Buy tokens 選 TUS，會自動開啟 Trader Joe 幫你跳回 C-Chain 並 import TUS 代幣進Swap，你只要兌換你需要的數量即可（可以先看看市場3隻地板價寄居蟹大概要多少 TUS）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HHx0nKuMoiWKpuv4gu3np.png?height=261&width=1144)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/h_aX-X96E9K4slW6t0-Z7.png?height=650&width=1154)

> **第五步｜把 TUS bridge 到 Swimmer Network**

我們買到的 TUS 是在 C-Chain 上，我們需要把它橋到 Swimmer Network 上，很簡單我們回到 Carbada 的Account 頁面，點擊 Bridge 會新開一個 Swimmer Network 各種橋的頁面，選擇 Layer Zero Bridge（From: Avalanche ; To: Swimmer Network ; Token: TUS），確定好數量按 Bridge。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/EPHQEZEVqOOautfh3MlO6.png?height=397&width=1200)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Y-rkNVBDNmtN8TYy2SOil.png?height=738&width=1131)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/pRkZKN_1R1xtJ9P5x-Fwm.png?height=661&width=1200)

> **第六步｜購買寄居蟹戰士NFT**

現在我們 Swimmer Network 上有 TUS 了，終於可以去 Marketplace 買自己喜歡的寄居蟹戰士了，大家一開始先從地板價挑 3 隻買就可以了，建議至少買一隻坦克類型的（Fraction:ORE，下圖這四隻就是坦克屬性）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/W7yu6IZyLU2oLuWOplikv.png?height=668&width=1369)

> **第七步｜將寄居蟹戰士NFT轉移到 Game account 中**

到 Account 頁面點擊 Transfer Crabada 勾選剛剛買的 Crabada 轉移到 Game account！

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/MpGZ0FTDaqbbEu_y9SMXB.png?height=399&width=1197)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/uoJVVMnF8cy0zN3vA3Zdi.png?height=781&width=1197)

> **第八步｜下載遊戲 App 開始遊戲**

到[官方網站](https://www.crabada.com/#battle)下載自己裝置版本的遊戲 App ，下載完後進入 App 選擇 Login 填入 Email 點 Send code，信箱會收到 OTP 使用其密碼進入遊戲。恭喜你成功開始 Crabada 的旅程了！

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/d1iBooPncHCBNGPJnBzxj.png?height=490&width=1329)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KV4fTYYV9ksM-lvfjIW8J.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/AOL449gQiu50IuAA0JZUq.png?height=1080&width=2340)


---

### 遊戲模式介紹

OK！ 現在我們完成了所有準備步驟，終於可以開始玩遊戲了！目前遊戲內容大致分為以下幾種模式，我會一一進行簡單的介紹！

1. 冒險模式
2. 挖寶模式
3. 搶劫模式
4. 角色升等
5. 戰利品兌換
6. PvP模式

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KNfpWkmZCWvLGk0LDKZQW.png?height=475&width=1033)

> **1 - 冒險模式**

使用你的 Crabada 3隻一組組成隊伍闖關，可以無限次嘗試可過關的擺陣方式與組合～（放前排的角色會優先被攻擊，如果同一排沒有攻擊目標會優先轉而攻擊上面一排的角色）

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vfxmradxsqi7ByxMEYA6t.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/N4dHRFMIVAybvIevsMi3H.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/VwLY1ri8AHsfj0zEy-Fty.png?height=1080&width=2340)

> **2 - 挖寶模式**

送你的 Crabada 出去挖礦，是我們主要的獲利方式。一次 1 小時，花費 4 點閃電點數（用完了每天會回滿）。挖礦時會有人來搶劫你，會自動發生戰鬥，贏或輸會影響獎勵（下圖可以看到角色屬性克制圖），時間到了再回來 Claim 獎勵即可，挖礦期間還是可以繼續玩闖關模式沒問題的！

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/tpAPxy4VqdIRNB09CE8A4.png?height=565&width=1227)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/VCgjT2gWVTURWJv2DbC4t.png?height=559&width=1224)

> **3 - 搶劫模式**

除了挖礦，我們也可以選擇去搶劫別人（也是會發生戰鬥），每次 30 分鐘，花費 1 點閃電。輸贏影響獎勵，時間到了可去 Claim。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0L2od2gmGU2-aIvlOdaBr.png?height=563&width=1225)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/I53ISJC8ExAjWGZ5f9Dk3.png?height=562&width=1224)

> **4 - 角色升等**

為了在每次戰鬥無往不利，我們的角色需要升等，也需要餵飽。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-UToWDYXjGfQ2ZaaS7ZtR.png?height=495&width=1073)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1ZtEdGgbqRgI98Jrw5DyU.png?height=591&width=1243)

> **5 - 戰利品兌換**

透過挖礦與搶劫獲得的戰利品，可以在此換成 TUS 或是食物。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vWid8z1-v23t9MZM2IawZ.png?height=1080&width=2340)

> **6 - PvP 模式**

最新的模式，官方即將開放新的錦標賽功能。目前我們可以透過 Host 創建挑戰，或是通過 Scan 加入別人的挑戰，來跟其他玩家的隊伍進行PK。贏家可以拿回 Duel Cost，輸家的 Duel Cost 則會被燒掉（而不是被贏家獲得）。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/MkKdXvWPFk-FMtVM_3_H7.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/I5z5kQPYd800Nwzedmvpc.png?height=1080&width=2340)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/GZqsZiJdZ9ff4vmzG2vmw.png?height=1080&width=2340)


---

### 結尾

至此已經將整個入門 Crabada 的流程完整的順過一遍了。祝大家可以愉快的遊戲，獲得不錯的收益與遊戲體驗囉～ Peace Out！

title: It’s time to sync your marketing & sales
body:
Stories that tell of the mistrust between Sales and Marketing are the stuff of legend in the business. Sales say they make the money and Marketing just spends it. Marketing says Sales would make more money if they gave Marketing more to spend.

![Photo by Merakist on Unsplash](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*SZCWq-vjGpcn4iB8fOgfVw.jpeg)

In the new world of digital marketing, marketers work with analysts, engineers, and thousands of highly technical KPIs. So the gap between Sales and Marketing is increasing in many companies. But not in the really successful companies.

In successful companies, Sales and Marketing sing from the same songbook and pitch from the same brand book. They’re both measured by sales results and KPIs. Sop, they speak the same language. And they understand each other. They understand the need to share information and play nicely as one big happy, growth-focused family.

Today’s Sales and Marketing processes involve a massive amount of testing, learning, scaling and fine-tuning. How in tune and aligned are your Marketing and Sales departments? To get them on the same page, and heading in the same direction, you need to shape their thinking and put a blueprint together for how they’ll work in the future. This is the first step in getting both teams to speak the same language. Then you’ll need to teach them to share.

Sales should share as much information about what happened on the last mile leading to a conversion. So Marketing can help make Sales’ work easier by sharing targeting, content, and calls-to-action knowledge. And Marketing should share its info about the lead so that Sales has all the info it needs to create a personal and contextual approach to a hot lead for Sales to follow up on. The audit will help you assess how aligned your Marketing and Sales teams are.

At Leadnostic, we developed an audit to measure the maturity of this bond. It is part of the Marketing DNA Assessment group of audits, and you can take it on leadnostic.com 
 Once you’ve completed it why not take a look at the other audits in the group — the Brand Identity, Target Audience, Customer Journey, Marketing Content, Organization, and Platforms Audits. It takes less than 10 minutes to complete and will give you access to a free analysis based on your results.

title: advance
body:
The advancement of modern technology is making peoples life more comfortable and at the same time less human. To those who enjoy the benefits of technology, there is no better time to be alive than now, but to others life has been increasingly complex and stressful. The issue is whether such new technological machines as computers and the Internet would be our servants forever or eventually could become our masters.

　　All kinds of inventions made possible by technology are designed to be the slaves of human beings, if human beings are not to be slaved by machines. Once upon a time, we were plain people, but that was before we began having relationships with technological systems. By getting involved with computerized machines, we could not help changing the way we live and the way we work, for better or for worse It can be realized that life is more complex because much of modern technology is not born to meet primary human needs, and many unnecessary inventions are producing negative effects on a living style that used to be relatively simple. Thus, there is an overwhelming feeling of complexity in the sense that machines act like humans and humans act like machines. Now that intelligent machines such as robots are widely applied to take the place of human beings because they are capable of doing many useful jobs, although making many people joblesss. Those who cannot work with computers are disadvantaged and therefore helpless while the traditional skills and simple ways of life are fading away, never to return again.

title: Toys, Secrets, and Cycles: Lessons from the 2000s
body:
I started my internet career in the early 2000s during the dot-com bust. It's hard to picture this now, but the internet was a thing that people used only intermittently, to check email or plan travel or do some research. The average internet user spent about 30 minutes a day online, compared to about 7 hours today. To use the internet, you had to sit down in front of a desktop PC and "log on" (most people still had dial-up), nothing like the always-on, high-speed mobile internet we use today. In 2001, Amazon's stock price hit an [all-time](https://companiesmarketcap.com/amazon/marketcap/) [low](https://www.zdnet.com/article/amazon-cash-to-run-dry-by-2001/), with a market cap of $2.2B, about 1/500th of what it is today. A prominent research firm [published](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2003/05/18/broadband-adoption-at-home/) a study asking Americans if they'd adopt broadband and the majority said no. Email was the most popular internet use case and they didn’t see the need to make it faster. The National Academy of Sciences [ranked](http://www.greatachievements.org/) the internet 13th in its list of great inventions over the last 100 years, beneath radio and telephones. The mainstream consensus was that the internet was a cool invention, but had limited use cases, and probably wasn't a good place to build a business.

At the same time, there was a small but growing movement of developers and founders who were excited about the idea that the internet could be more than a read-only medium – that it could allow anyone to create and publish, to not only read but also write, as we said back then. This movement became known as web 2. The runner up name was read-write web. (These are not after-the-fact terms: there were [prominent](https://www.oreilly.com/pub/a/web2/archive/what-is-web-20.html) publications and conferences that used them.)

The key web 2 concepts were: letting users publish whatever they want (“user generated content” was a buzzword), social graphs, APIs and [mashups](https://avc.com/2006/08/business_develo/) (what we'd call [composability](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1451703067213066244?s=20&t=OMwnAHagQ1wsTRv-Bre-wA) today), defaulting profiles and photos to public vs private, and tagging over hierarchical navigation, among other things. There were also technical innovations. A seemingly simple but important one was web pages that updated dynamically without reloading the page, what was usually called [Ajax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming)) and is now just the way people expect web apps to work. There were mobile devices that could access the open web but they were extremely niche (I was an avid [Sidekick](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMNDqO2HjEU) user).

One striking thing about that period was the contrast between what smart founders and engineers talked about at dinner and on weekends and what the mainstream tech world took seriously during work days. For example, one popular mainstream trend was enterprise security appliances, which were basically servers preloaded with security software. Many of the very same people would go to work and talk about the “serious” products, and then go to dinner, or hang out on the weekends, and talk about consumer internet products and web 2. It was the most interesting thing happening in tech. But generally, the view was, web 2 products were toys that couldn't be real businesses. They were hobbies, and not something you would take seriously during the workday.

One lesson for me, which took me some time to learn, and that eventually led to some blog posts I wrote, including “[The next thing big thing will start out looking like a toy](https://cdixon.org/2010/01/03/the-next-big-thing-will-start-out-looking-like-a-toy)” and “[What the smartest people do on the weekend is what everyone else will do during the week in ten years](https://cdixon.org/2013/03/02/what-the-smartest-people-do-on-the-weekend-is-what-everyone-else-will-do-during-the-week-in-ten-years),” is that there's a strong correlation between rich product design spaces and what smart people find interesting. Web 2 was captivating, and led to so many dinner and weekend conversations, because there were so many novel product design possibilities. What if you took this feature and that feature and combined them? What if you applied this design pattern to a different context? What original product concepts would be invented next? This is what got people so excited. In contrast, the “serious stuff,” security appliances and such, seemed much more limited in their possibilities.

Another striking thing about that period was how small and passionate the web 2 community was. I remember in 2004 going to what I think might have been the first New York Tech meetup. The whole group fit in a small room in Meetup’s headquarters. People demoed software they had created and talked late into the evening. I still have friends from that period. Sometimes I get asked how I first met old friends like Fred Wilson and Alexis Ohanian. The simple answer is there just weren't that many people, especially on the east coast, who were interested in these topics. We all knew each other. It was a real community. I have one old friend Alex Rampell (who now works with me at a16z) who I met in 2003 because a friend of mine was at a dinner party and afterwards said “Hey, I met someone else who's interested in consumer internet.” It was that rare. But people were very focused and excited. The feeling was that a revolution was brewing. We knew a secret and the rest of the world hadn't figured it out yet.

As for me, I was working on my own web 2 startup called SiteAdvisor. Around 2003, when my co-founders and I started developing the concept, web security threats were spiraling out of control. Most people used PCs with Internet Explorer, and problems like phishing and spyware were widespread. The idea for SiteAdvisor was that we’d start off with a tool that would warn users about security threats like phishing and spyware, and then, over time, applying web 2 concepts like user-generated reviews, layer on more subjective judgements (similar to what [TrustPilot](https://www.trustpilot.com/) seems to do today). This staged approach was common at the time, a strategy I later characterized as “[Come for the tool, stay for the network](https://cdixon.org/2015/01/31/come-for-the-tool-stay-for-the-network).” We built APIs and encouraged mashups and did most of our marketing through SEO.

2005 was a big year for web 2 because of two acquisitions, Flickr and Delicious, both by Yahoo. The dollar values were small by today’s standards, something like $30M each, but it was an important signal. The assumption up until then was that web 2 was a fun hobby, a way to build cool stuff, but not something that would produce real businesses. Yahoo was considered a savvy company, and said they were making web 2 a core part of their strategy.

As I recall, that was the point when web 2 started transitioning from a niche cult movement into mainstream tech. Some of the early web 2 founders successfully made the transition. In other cases new entrepreneurs came along who built on the work of the early enthusiasts. The basis of competition switched from creative idea generation to disciplined execution. You had to decide whether you wanted to be the idealistic band at the indy bar or be pragmatic — potentially making compromises — and play in stadiums.

By 2007, things were looking up for web 2. Among other things, Facebook passed 10M users, Twitter was growing and had just gotten VC funded, and Google acquired YouTube. Then the 2008 financial crisis hit, which was a gut check for entrepreneurs. Tech funding dried up, and a lot of smart people said we were on the [verge](https://articles.sequoiacap.com/rip-good-times) of another great depression.

The financial downturn was a difficult time for many people. But from a startup perspective, the 2008-11 era turned out to be a golden age. Apple released the iPhone app store in 2008 and by 2009 talented founders were pouring in. The mobile app revolution was in full swing. Almost all of today’s top mobile apps were created by companies founded between 2009 and 2011, including Uber, Venmo, Snap, and Instagram. In retrospect, there was a convergence of three powerful trends: social media (by then that word was replacing web 2), cloud computing (which would enable the apps to scale server side), and the rise of smartphones. Independent product design spaces are multiplicative: even if social, cloud, and mobile each improved linearly, the combination could improve exponentially.

I made the chart below to summarize how I've come to think about product and financial cycles. The key idea is that product and financial cycles evolve mostly independently. The top of the chart shows the Nasdaq index as a rough proxy for financial sentiment. Financial sentiment fluctuates unpredictably and sometimes wildly.

The next row shows the years that iconic startups or products were created. The timing is mostly dictated by product cycles, which are shown in the bottom row. Product cycles follow their own internal logic and tend to be more predictable than financial cycles. They begin with the incubation phase when enthusiasts explore ideas on nights and weekends and build products that are mostly used by other enthusiasts. The growth phase arrives when the right mix of technology, talent, and community knowledge comes together to enable the products to go mainstream. (I show the biggest tech cycles in the chart, but smaller, offshoot tech cycles happen as well, including web 2 in the 2000s, and things like fintech and SaaS in the 2010s.)

![Financial cycles and product cycles](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Ps4OuwnY01u396r29UKzn.png?height=1174&width=1554)

Tech is very different today than in the 2000s. A handful of tech incumbents dominate the internet, exerting vast economic and cultural influence. In the 2000s, web 2 was mostly ignored or dismissed as techies talking about trivialities. Today, entrenched interests aggressively respond to new movements that might someday threaten them. But the same creative patterns that happened in the 2000s live on today, driven by enthusiasts who see possibilities where others don’t. You just need to know where to look. My belief is that the best place to look is crypto and web 3.

From my vantage point, today’s negative financial sentiment most closely resembles 2008. If we are headed for a prolonged downturn, there are some tactical lessons from the 2008 era, namely preserving capital and staying focused on your long-term vision. The strategic lesson is to keep your eyes squarely focused on the product cycle. Things that look interesting to smart people usually do so because they are rich with product possibilities. These possibilities eventually become reality. Toys become must-have tools. Weekend hobbies become mainstream activities. Cynics sound smart but optimists build the future.

title: How your customer journey mapping impacts your marketing funnel.
body:
![Photo by Matt Duncan on Unsplash](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*by431F8UXvPEmxdxIZvUJQ.jpeg)

There are three basic models for setting up a lead-generation marketing funnel. Some companies choose to set up their funnel from a platform-first perspective. They create a social media presence, launch a website, invest in marketing automation, implement a CRM solution, or all of the above. Then they cross their fingers and wait for customers; a build-it-and-hope-they’ll-come approach. Others choose an organic-content-versus-paid-content type of approach. And the smart ones choose a completely different perspective: the customer-first approach.

Let’s look at it from your customer’s point of view. And let’s face it, they just want to find their way to a product or service that solves their problem, fulfils their need or soothes their desire. This is important to know when setting up your lead generation funnel, because really, your business should be all about your customer. So should your marketing. And your marketing funnel. But how do you move your leads through the funnel, from anonymous consumers to loyal customers?

You need to be able to define the maturity of your leads, so you know where they are on the customer journey. You need to be able to define the lead’s characteristics at every stage of the funnel. And you need to know what the triggers are that move them from one level of maturity to the next.

Then you need to take all your learnings so you can create the all-important map for the entire customer journey. Along with the work you do around your Target Audience and Brand Identity, the work on your Customer Journey completes the groundwork you need to do before you build any tool or launch any marketing channel.

title: Toys, Secrets, and Cycles: Lessons from the 2000s
body:
I started my internet career in the early 2000s during the dot-com bust. It's hard to picture this now, but the internet was a thing that people used only intermittently, to check email or plan travel or do some research. The average internet user spent about 30 minutes a day online, compared to about 7 hours today. To use the internet, you had to sit down in front of a desktop PC and "log on" (most people still had dial-up), nothing like the always-on, high-speed mobile internet we use today. In 2001, Amazon's stock price hit an [all-time](https://companiesmarketcap.com/amazon/marketcap/) [low](https://www.zdnet.com/article/amazon-cash-to-run-dry-by-2001/), with a market cap of $2.2B, about 1/500th of what it is today. A prominent research firm [published](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2003/05/18/broadband-adoption-at-home/) a study asking Americans if they'd adopt broadband and the majority said no. Email was the most popular internet use case and they didn’t see the need to make it faster. The National Academy of Sciences [ranked](http://www.greatachievements.org/) the internet 13th in its list of great inventions over the last 100 years, beneath radio and telephones. The mainstream consensus was that the internet was a cool invention, but had limited use cases, and probably wasn't a good place to build a business.

At the same time, there was a small but growing movement of developers and founders who were excited about the idea that the internet could be more than a read-only medium – that it could allow anyone to create and publish, to not only read but also write, as we said back then. This movement became known as web 2. The runner up name was read-write web. (These are not after-the-fact terms: there were [prominent](https://www.oreilly.com/pub/a/web2/archive/what-is-web-20.html) publications and conferences that used them.)

The key web 2 concepts were: letting users publish whatever they want (“user generated content” was a buzzword), social graphs, APIs and [mashups](https://avc.com/2006/08/business_develo/) (what we'd call [composability](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1451703067213066244?s=20&t=OMwnAHagQ1wsTRv-Bre-wA) today), defaulting profiles and photos to public vs private, and tagging over hierarchical navigation, among other things. There were also technical innovations. A seemingly simple but important one was web pages that updated dynamically without reloading the page, what was usually called [Ajax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming)) and is now just the way people expect web apps to work. There were mobile devices that could access the open web but they were extremely niche (I was an avid [Sidekick](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMNDqO2HjEU) user).

One striking thing about that period was the contrast between what smart founders and engineers talked about at dinner and on weekends and what the mainstream tech world took seriously during work days. For example, one popular mainstream trend was enterprise security appliances, which were basically servers preloaded with security software. Many of the very same people would go to work and talk about the “serious” products, and then go to dinner, or hang out on the weekends, and talk about consumer internet products and web 2. It was the most interesting thing happening in tech. But generally, the view was, web 2 products were toys that couldn't be real businesses. They were hobbies, and not something you would take seriously during the workday.

One lesson for me, which took me some time to learn, and that eventually led to some blog posts I wrote, including “[The next thing big thing will start out looking like a toy](https://cdixon.org/2010/01/03/the-next-big-thing-will-start-out-looking-like-a-toy)” and “[What the smartest people do on the weekend is what everyone else will do during the week in ten years](https://cdixon.org/2013/03/02/what-the-smartest-people-do-on-the-weekend-is-what-everyone-else-will-do-during-the-week-in-ten-years),” is that there's a strong correlation between rich product design spaces and what smart people find interesting. Web 2 was captivating, and led to so many dinner and weekend conversations, because there were so many novel product design possibilities. What if you took this feature and that feature and combined them? What if you applied this design pattern to a different context? What original product concepts would be invented next? This is what got people so excited. In contrast, the “serious stuff,” security appliances and such, seemed much more limited in their possibilities.

Another striking thing about that period was how small and passionate the web 2 community was. I remember in 2004 going to what I think might have been the first New York Tech meetup. The whole group fit in a small room in Meetup’s headquarters. People demoed software they had created and talked late into the evening. I still have friends from that period. Sometimes I get asked how I first met old friends like Fred Wilson and Alexis Ohanian. The simple answer is there just weren't that many people, especially on the east coast, who were interested in these topics. We all knew each other. It was a real community. I have one old friend Alex Rampell (who now works with me at a16z) who I met in 2003 because a friend of mine was at a dinner party and afterwards said “Hey, I met someone else who's interested in consumer internet.” It was that rare. But people were very focused and excited. The feeling was that a revolution was brewing. We knew a secret and the rest of the world hadn't figured it out yet.

As for me, I was working on my own web 2 startup called SiteAdvisor. Around 2003, when my co-founders and I started developing the concept, web security threats were spiraling out of control. Most people used PCs with Internet Explorer, and problems like phishing and spyware were widespread. The idea for SiteAdvisor was that we’d start off with a tool that would warn users about security threats like phishing and spyware, and then, over time, applying web 2 concepts like user-generated reviews, layer on more subjective judgements (similar to what [TrustPilot](https://www.trustpilot.com/) seems to do today). This staged approach was common at the time, a strategy I later characterized as “[Come for the tool, stay for the network](https://cdixon.org/2015/01/31/come-for-the-tool-stay-for-the-network).” We built APIs and encouraged mashups and did most of our marketing through SEO.

2005 was a big year for web 2 because of two acquisitions, Flickr and Delicious, both by Yahoo. The dollar values were small by today’s standards, something like $30M each, but it was an important signal. The assumption up until then was that web 2 was a fun hobby, a way to build cool stuff, but not something that would produce real businesses. Yahoo was considered a savvy company, and said they were making web 2 a core part of their strategy.

As I recall, that was the point when web 2 started transitioning from a niche cult movement into mainstream tech. Some of the early web 2 founders successfully made the transition. In other cases new entrepreneurs came along who built on the work of the early enthusiasts. The basis of competition switched from creative idea generation to disciplined execution. You had to decide whether you wanted to be the idealistic band at the indy bar or be pragmatic — potentially making compromises — and play in stadiums.

By 2007, things were looking up for web 2. Among other things, Facebook passed 10M users, Twitter was growing and had just gotten VC funded, and Google acquired YouTube. Then the 2008 financial crisis hit, which was a gut check for entrepreneurs. Tech funding dried up, and a lot of smart people said we were on the [verge](https://articles.sequoiacap.com/rip-good-times) of another great depression.

The financial downturn was a difficult time for many people. But from a startup perspective, the 2008-11 era turned out to be a golden age. Apple released the iPhone app store in 2008 and by 2009 talented founders were pouring in. The mobile app revolution was in full swing. Almost all of today’s top mobile apps were created by companies founded between 2009 and 2011, including Uber, Venmo, Snap, and Instagram. In retrospect, there was a convergence of three powerful trends: social media (by then that word was replacing web 2), cloud computing (which would enable the apps to scale server side), and the rise of smartphones. Independent product design spaces are multiplicative: even if social, cloud, and mobile each improved linearly, the combination could improve exponentially.

I made the chart below to summarize how I've come to think about product and financial cycles. The key idea is that product and financial cycles evolve mostly independently. The top of the chart shows the Nasdaq index as a rough proxy for financial sentiment. Financial sentiment fluctuates unpredictably and sometimes wildly.

The next row shows the years that iconic startups or products were created. The timing is mostly dictated by product cycles, which are shown in the bottom row. Product cycles follow their own internal logic and tend to be more predictable than financial cycles. They begin with the incubation phase when enthusiasts explore ideas on nights and weekends and build products that are mostly used by other enthusiasts. The growth phase arrives when the right mix of technology, talent, and community knowledge comes together to enable the products to go mainstream. (I show the biggest tech cycles in the chart, but smaller, offshoot tech cycles happen as well, including web 2 in the 2000s, and things like fintech and SaaS in the 2010s.)

![Financial cycles and product cycles](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Ps4OuwnY01u396r29UKzn.png?height=1174&width=1554)

Tech is very different today than in the 2000s. A handful of tech incumbents dominate the internet, exerting vast economic and cultural influence. In the 2000s, web 2 was mostly ignored or dismissed as techies talking about trivialities. Today, entrenched interests aggressively respond to new movements that might someday threaten them. But the same creative patterns that happened in the 2000s live on today, driven by enthusiasts who see possibilities where others don’t. You just need to know where to look. My belief is that the best place to look is crypto and web 3.

From my vantage point, today’s negative financial sentiment most closely resembles 2008. If we are headed for a prolonged downturn, there are some tactical lessons from the 2008 era, namely preserving capital and staying focused on your long-term vision. The strategic lesson is to keep your eyes squarely focused on the product cycle. Things that look interesting to smart people usually do so because they are rich with product possibilities. These possibilities eventually become reality. Toys become must-have tools. Weekend hobbies become mainstream activities. Cynics sound smart but optimists build the future.

title: It’s time to sync your marketing & Sales
body:
Stories that tell of the mistrust between Sales and Marketing are the stuff of legend in the business. Sales say they make the money and Marketing just spends it. Marketing says Sales would make more money if they gave Marketing more to spend.

![Photo by Merakist on Unsplash](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*SZCWq-vjGpcn4iB8fOgfVw.jpeg)

In the new world of digital marketing, marketers work with analysts, engineers, and thousands of highly technical KPIs. So the gap between Sales and Marketing is increasing in many companies. But not in the really successful companies.

In successful companies, Sales and Marketing sing from the same songbook and pitch from the same brand book. They’re both measured by sales results and KPIs. Sop, they speak the same language. And they understand each other. They understand the need to share information and play nicely as one big happy, growth-focused family.

Today’s Sales and Marketing processes involve a massive amount of testing, learning, scaling and fine-tuning. How in tune and aligned are your Marketing and Sales departments? To get them on the same page, and heading in the same direction, you need to shape their thinking and put a blueprint together for how they’ll work in the future. This is the first step in getting both teams to speak the same language. Then you’ll need to teach them to share.

Sales should share as much information about what happened on the last mile leading to a conversion. So Marketing can help make Sales’ work easier by sharing targeting, content, and calls-to-action knowledge. And Marketing should share its info about the lead so that Sales has all the info it needs to create a personal and contextual approach to a hot lead for Sales to follow up on. The audit will help you assess how aligned your Marketing and Sales teams are.

At Leadnostic, we developed an audit to measure the maturity of this bond. It is part of the Marketing DNA Assessment group of audits, and you can take it on leadnostic.com

title: Why your marketing funnel architecture is key
body:
Marketing is about positioning your business’s brand and promoting your business’s products and services. So it makes sense to align your marketing objectives to your business objectives.

![Brands&People via Unsplash](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*3t_B1Wnv1x1IA0jbPCh4pA.jpeg)

At [Leadnostic](https://leadnostic.com/), the aim of all our audits is to help you assess your marketing unit so that it delivers against your business objectives. For Marketing to operate at peak efficiency, you need to run a scalable lead-generation funnel. The only way to scale your funnel effectively is to build it using rational, standardized thinking. We developed an audit that looks at how to do just that.

We first recommend that you look into our audit for Sales & Marketing Alignment, in which we look at syncing both departments for more unified, more successful outcomes. This is achieved by linking the KPIs of both departments, which are in turn, linked to the business objectives.

Once this process is in place, Marketing can match their objectives with their Target Audience strategy; who they wish to target, what they wish to say, what kind of content to say it with, and which channels to say it through. To do this successfully you’ll need to formalize it in a document. Then you’ll have a blueprint, which will guide you through the complex world of marketing platforms. It will also help you optimize all your marketing activities, by reverse-engineering the process. This begins by optimizing your content and marketing channels.

Then you’ll be able to observe any shifts in how effective your processes are that take your Target Audience members from anonymous users through the funnel to become actual customers. This ultimately helps you redefine your Target Audience, and helps you measure the impact and efficiency of your content and your channel strategies.

Optimizing your lead-generation funnel is not a set-and-forget process. It requires constant attention to be able to help you monitor, react and respond to the ever-changing marketing environment. You need to be able to fine-tune it, tweak it, and scale it, so it grows and evolves as needs be.

The marketing process audit is one of three in a series of audits that assesses your Lead Generation Funnel. The other two audits focus on people and platforms and will give you a more operational perspective of your marketing and lead-generation funnel.

The audit takes less than 10 minutes to complete and will give you access to a free analysis based on your results.

Get on [leadnostic.com](https://leadnostic.com/) for more info and for a free initial assessment of your marketing architecture maturity.

title: Into the Abyss...
body:
If you are reading this at the time of publishing, and for some reason, you scour through my social media, you will notice that I have the same profile picture throughout my socials. No, it’s not because it’s an obscure NFT that I’m trying to promote, but rather a choice in the philosophical nature.

For those who haven’t played Dark Souls, allow me to introduce one of my favorite videogame characters: Knight Artorias, the Abysswalker. I’ll briefly summarize Artorias and how he is relevant to my social media presence and goals.

With the growing threat of the Abyss swallowing the kingdom whole, Lord Gwyn, king of Lordran, sends Artorias and his canine companion, Sif, on a quest to rid the world of the Abyss. Though the most skilled warrior in all the land, at the very heart of the Abyss, Artorias meets Manus, Father of the Abyss. Manus proves to be indomitable for Artorias. Before succumbing to the Abyss and his doom, Artorias casts a spell over Sif to protect it from the wretched Abyss. Sif is left for the player’s character, The Chosen Undead, to rescue, and the player is set to finish what the Abysswalker started, defeat Manus, and cast away the Abyss.

To me, the story of Artorias is one of the most interesting backstories of an NPC.

But why am I telling you this?

The crypto space can sometimes feel like an abyss. It feels like there’s too much to learn; everything moves fast, Bitcoin’s up, Bitcoin’s down, Bull market, Bear market… It can be a tad overwhelming to get in. This is especially true if your educational/previous career is not finance or tech-based.

This leads me to another bit of the philosophy of Dark Souls. “Git Gud” is something that may be infuriating to hear for frustrated gamers out here, but it is, in fact, a very reassuring line. To beat the game, all one has to do is “Git Gud.“ It doesn’t matter what level you are or even what leveled armor and weapons you have. If you don’t “Git Gud,“ you’re doomed to die endless deaths.

My goal is to implement this “Git Gud“ mentality, find possibly worthwhile DeFi/GameFi projects, and do a deep dive into what they are, who they are, and what they do. This provides me with a “hands-on” type of learning experience. Hopefully, I can provide some valuable information for you, my reader.

I am not, however, a financial expert. I am neither a software engineer nor an expert in blockchain technology. I want my readers to know this as I write more articles; I am not an expert. Please take what I say with a grain of salt.

I hope that through these analyses and updates, I may shed light on an otherwise abysmal dark forest of an ecosystem to whoever is willing to read and trek along with me on this journey.

Remember, git gud, and don’t you dare go hollow…

title: Why defining your Target Audience matters — and why you should audit your methodology
body:
Many businesses make the mistake of approaching their marketing with an inside-out strategy, by placing their product at the center of their focus. Sure, this approach may sound like the right way to go-to-market. But maybe not

![wes lewis via Unsplash](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*cXaTHP2T-TO-GPAwIhtIfw.jpeg)

But this inward-looking, product-led approach is all about your company, not your customer. It places all the pressure on your sales team to convert your more accessible customers, in order to get results. It will work for a while, but once this stream dries up you’ll need to look beyond. You’ll need to reach out and attract new customers who have never heard of you. This requires more of an outside-in approach — a customer-first approach.

To do this, you’ll need to reverse your thinking and place your target audience at the center of your focus. Then you can tailor your marketing message to tell them how you can help solve their problem or fulfill their need. Don’t look inwards, look outwards. This customer-first, benefits-led approach will help you take your message further and grow your market and your sales.

[Leadnostic’s](https://platform.leadnostic.com/) Target Audience Audit will help you assess your approach to your Target Audience. You’ll discover your stronger components and those that need strengthening. So your Target Audience communication strategy will become a stronger building block in your brand matrix. Then we’d recommend you assess how well your marketing and sales teams are in sync with our Sales and Marketing Teams Alignment Audit.

The most important marketing KPI is SQL/MQL. This measures how to convert marketing-qualified leads into sales-qualified leads. These KPIs help you determine the quality of the leads marketing delivers. It also helps measure how well your sales and marketing teams are in sync. You will discover your Target Audience at the root of your SQL and MQL.

This audit takes less than 10 minutes to complete and will give you access to a free analysis based on your results. It is part of the Marketing DNA Assessment group of audits. Once you’ve completed it why not take a look at the other audits in the group — the Brand Identity, Content, Customer Journey, Marketing & Sales Sync, Organization, and Platforms Audits. Visit it on Leadnostic.com

title: LooksRare 合约代码解读（二）
body:
我们继续来学习 LooksRare 的代码，[上篇文章](https://mirror.xyz/xyyme.eth/mlRnXcw-eg2Xeoctg54mDU08msmUt4LLnOy4-4WTQyo)中我们学习了它的主合约 `LooksRareExchange`，这篇文章我们着重于其它的辅助合约，包括各种管理合约以及交易策略合约等。

## 源码解读

### TransferSelectorNFT

上篇文章的最后，我们谈到了 NFT 的转账操作：

![NFT 转账](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-2AeRHcXiSymbbM_4K0Pw.png?height=926&width=1952&&&size=medium)

可以看到，需要先根据 NFT 地址获取相应的转账管理器，然后采用对应的管理器来进行转账。其内部的实现为：

![获取 NFT 对应的转账管理合约](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3LsitXFmmHhJcOvfWvJNw.png?height=1448&width=2370&&&size=medium)

这段代码中先查询该 NFT 有没有特定的转账管理器。如果没有，则利用 ERC165 规范，查询 NFT 合约实现了哪种规范（ERC721 或 ERC1155），然后使用对应的通用管理器。转账管理器本身的合约代码很简单，例如 ERC721 的转账代码为：

### TransferManagerERC721

![ERC721 转账管理器](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/i-84B56PGKkOuawh8kd6N.png?height=798&width=1896&&&size=medium)

### Manager

`CurrencyManager`，`ExecutionManager` 这两个管理器合约内容比较简单，包含基本的 `add`，`remove`，`view` 等方法，我们这里不再介绍。

### RoyaltyFeeRegistry

该合约用于存储版税的相关信息，包括设置，读取等方法。

其中设置方法只能由 owner，即 `RoyaltyFeeSetter` 合约调用。

![版税数据结构](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/s2HUwnSuHxZhSMwLIFnPk.png?height=876&width=1670)

![版税对应的相关方法](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cQJHt_ixMix6W0Svk4ppS.png?height=2440&width=2204&&size=medium)

### RoyaltyFeeSetter

设置版税信息，可以理解为将上面的 `RoyaltyFeeRegistry` 合约包装了一层，这里是设置的入口。包含下面几个主要方法：

* `updateRoyaltyInfoForCollectionIfAdmin`
* `updateRoyaltyInfoForCollectionIfOwner`
* `updateRoyaltyInfoForCollectionIfSetter`
* `updateRoyaltyInfoForCollection`
* `_updateRoyaltyInfoForCollectionIfOwnerOrAdmin`（内部方法，被上面的 `IfAdmin` 和 `IfOwner` 方法调用）

前四个方法均为设置版税功能，区别在于，前两个是由 NFT 的管理员设置，由于每个 NFT 合约的写法都不同，因此会区分 `admin`，`owner` 等角色。第三个方法是由前面设置版税时的 setter 设置。第四个是由 `RoyaltyFeeSetter` 合约本身的 owner 调用。注意前两个方法只能在没有设置 setter 的时候调用。最后一个内部方法调用上面的 `registry` 合约，进行设置操作。

我们来看看其中一个设置方法：

#### updateRoyaltyInfoForCollectionIfAdmin

![设置版税](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/m7TD11_p17Tgu0YP0-OdJ.png?height=882&width=2106&size=medium)

逻辑比较简单。要求只有 NFT 的 admin 可以调用。我们看到第一步要求 NFT 不能实现 ERC2981，奇怪了，ERC2981 不就是版税的标准呢，为什么不能实现这个接口呢，我们后面会解答这个问题。

#### _updateRoyaltyInfoForCollectionIfOwnerOrAdmin

![更新版税内部方法](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/SE9tylSJUaK4WoPQq10PP.png?height=1294&width=2276&size=medium)

### RoyaltyFeeManager

该合约是最外层的接口，主合约在这里获取版税信息，只有一个主要方法：

#### calculateRoyaltyFeeAndGetRecipient

![版税外层接口](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/abck9z7FdZsfWAvg7BAw1.png?height=1112&width=2118&size=medium)

我们看到，首先要检查系统中是否设置了该 NFT 的版税信息，如果没有设置，再去检查 NFT 本身是否包含版税信息。反过来想，如果合约本身就已经包含了版税信息，那么我们就没有必要在系统中设置。这也就解答了我们前面提出的问题：在 `RoyaltyFeeSetter` 合约中设置版税时，要求 NFT 合约本身不能实现 ERC2981。因为实现了 ERC2981 的合约，我们直接使用其自身的版税信息即可，不必再次设置。

接下来我们看看交易策略，LooksRare 合约库中一共包含 5 个交易策略，分别是：

* `StrategyStandardSaleForFixedPrice`，标准固定价格交易
* `StrategyPrivateSale`，卖家指定的买家才能购买
* `StrategyDutchAuction`，荷兰拍卖
* `StrategyAnyItemFromCollectionForFixedPrice`，买家出价购买一个 NFT 合集中任意一项。例如，买家想购买 BAYC，任意一个都可以
* `StrategyAnyItemInASetForFixedPrice`，买家出价购买一个 NFT 合集中某些特定 tokenId 中任意一项。例如，买家只想购买蓝色背景的 BAYC

我们回想一下，在上篇文章中我们看到每个 `match` 成单方法都会调用策略的方法来校验该交易是否有效。例如：

![调用策略方法](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2UASec-TjV2r4oX9s4f-b.png?height=1942&width=2128&size=medium)

我们先提前了解一点，每个策略中都有两个主要方法：

* `canExecuteTakerAsk`，校验 taker 卖单与 maker 买单能否有效匹配
* `canExecuteTakerBid`，校验 taker 买单与 maker 卖单能否有效匹配

接下来我们分别来介绍每个策略的代码，看看他们的具体实现。

### StrategyStandardSaleForFixedPrice

最标准的买卖策略，固定价格，买单与卖单均指定 tokenId。

![标准策略](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/uXDiusHsYHw3POWA0hIYR.png?height=2720&width=2308&size=medium)

可以看到标准策略中需要校验 `price`、`tokenId` 是否匹配，并检查时间戳是否有效，逻辑比较简单。只要满足这些规则，就是符合标准策略。

### StrategyPrivateSale

当卖家指定由某位固定的买家购买时，使用该策略。

![指定买家](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/PIbMIFwjchwui3gKfJXu3.png?height=2554&width=2316&size=medium)

卖家指定买家，此时卖单挂单中会指定买家的地址，将其存放在 MakerOrder 的 `params` 字段。因为这个策略的执行只能由买家触发，所以 `canExecuteTakerAsk` 方法没有意义，需要返回 false。在下面的 `canExecuteTakerBid` 中，需要将卖家指定的买家地址从 `params` 中解析出来，然后进行校验，同时也要校验价格，tokenId，时间戳等信息。

### StrategyDutchAuction

荷兰拍卖，价格会不断下降，买家为主动方。

![荷兰拍卖](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/seTRX3JO28TLwtCTkb9Z4.png?height=3262&width=2484&size=medium)

荷兰拍卖同样由买家触发，因此 taker 卖单没有意义，`canExecuteTakerAsk` 需要返回 false。在 `canExecuteTakerBid` 方法中，根据开始价格，结束价格，拍卖时常来计算当前实时价格，最后对参数进行校验。

### StrategyAnyItemFromCollectionForFixedPrice

![买家购买任意一款](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/qzx5eKQ11Ev-fk9cHvknB.png?height=2222&width=2254&size=medium)

买家购买合集中任意一项均可，因此为买家挂单。此时卖家为 taker 主动方，因此 `canExecuteTakerBid` 没有意义，返回 false。我们看到，在 `canExecuteTakerAsk` 中仅仅校验了价格与时间，没有 tokenId，这是为何呢？因为买家购买任意一款均可，那么就不用指定 tokenId，只要价格与时间等信息匹配，任意一款 tokenId 都可以，因此这里不用校验。

### StrategyAnyItemInASetForFixedPrice

![买家购买某些特定 id](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/zJ4G6Sb6I4Uw4EBm8j8hS.png?height=2824&width=2298&size=medium)

买家指定购买某些特定的 tokenId，此时买家挂单，卖家为 taker 主动方，因此 `canExecuteTakerBid` 没有意义，返回 false。`canExecuteTakerAsk` 中利用了 Merkle Tree 的技术，maker 买单中的 `params` 字段存储所有想要购买 tokenId 合集的 Merkle Root，taker 卖单中的 `params` 存储了该 tokenId 对应的 Proof。最后通过 verify 校验 taker 卖单中的 tokenId 是否匹配。

## 总结

现在我们就已经介绍完了 LooksRare 的所有主要合约，是不是感觉还挺简单的。我个人认为 LooksRare 的文档和代码写得都比较简洁易懂，比较适合开发者来学习 NFT 市场的原理。希望大家能够结合代码库和我的文章，多理解几遍，必然会对自己的能力有一些提升。

## LooksRare 代码系列文章

1. [LooksRare 合约代码解读（一）](https://mirror.xyz/xyyme.eth/mlRnXcw-eg2Xeoctg54mDU08msmUt4LLnOy4-4WTQyo)
2. LooksRare 合约代码解读（二）
